section.title: Introduction
section.para: This is the raw socket interface, as described in sys/socket.h. Sockets are represented by their &fixnum-t; &file-des;s.
section.simpara: When this module is present, &features-var; contains the symbol :RAWSOCK.

warning.title: Try &socket-stream; first!
warning.simpara: For most uses of sockets, the facilities described in are adequate and much more convenient than these. You are encouraged to consider &socket-stream;s and ensure that they are not adequate for your purposes before you use raw sockets.

warning.title: Do &not-e; use &make-stream;!

section.title: Single System Call Functions
section.para:
We implement access to
(accept &sock-r; &addr-r;) (bind &sock-r; &addr-r;) (connect &sock-r; &addr-r;) (getaddrinfo &key-amp; node service protocol socktype family passive canonname numerichost numericserv v4mapped all addrconfig) (getnameinfo &addr-r; &key-amp; nofqdn numerichost namereqd numericserv numericscope dgram) (getpeername &sock-r; &addr-r;) (getsockname &sock-r; &addr-r;) (htonl &n-r;) (htons &n-r;) (ntohl &n-r;) (ntohs &n-r;) (recv &sock-r; &buf-r; &key-amp; start end peek oob waitall) (recvfrom &sock-r; &buf-r; &addr-r; &key-amp; start end peek oob waitall) (recvmsg &sock-r; &mesg-r; &key-amp; start end peek oob waitall) (send &sock-r; &buf-r; &key-amp; start end oob eor) (sendmsg &sock-r; &mesg-r; &key-amp; start end oob eor) (sendto &sock-r; &buf-r; &addr-r; &key-amp; start end oob eor) (sockatmark &sock-r;) (socket domain &type-r; &proto-r;) (socketpair domain &type-r; &proto-r;) using same-named lisp functions in package RAWSOCK. Additionally, (RAWSOCK:SOCK-CLOSE &sock-r;) calls close. (RAWSOCK:SOCK-LISTEN &sock-r; &optional-amp; (backlog SOMAXCONN)) calls listen.

listitem.simpara: A &ubyte-vec;. The vector may be adjustable and have a fill pointer. Whenever a function accepts a &buf-r; argument, it also accepts &start-k; and &end-k; keyword arguments with the usual meaning and defaults. You do not have to supply the vector length because Lisp can determine it itself, but, if you want to, you can use &end-k; argument for that.
A &nil; (stands for AF_UNSPEC), &integer-t;, or a platform-specific keyword, e.g., :INET stands for AF_INET.
A &nil; (stands for 0); &integer-t;; or a platform-specific keyword, e.g., :DGRAM stands for SOCK_DGRAM.
A &nil; (stands for 0); &integer-t;; a platform-specific keyword, e.g., :ETH_P_ARP stands for ETH_P_ARP, :IPPROTO-ICMP stands for IPPROTO_ICMP; or a &string-t; (passed to getprotobyname).
This &c-lang; argument corresponds to keyword arguments to the Lisp functions. E.g., rawsock:send accepts :OOB and EOR arguments, while rawsock:recv accepts PEEK, OOB and WAITALL.
A &structure-object-t; RAWSOCK:SOCKADDR returned by MAKE-SOCKADDR. You do not need to supply its length because Lisp can determine it itself.

section.title: Platform-dependent Keywords
section.para:
One can extract the list of acceptable platform-dependent keywords for, e.g., socket domain, using the following code:
(█ &nil; (&handler-bind; ((&type-error-t; (&lambda-m; (c) (&format; &t; "~&error: ~A~%" c) (&return; (&cddr; (&third; (&type-error-expected-type; c))))))) (rawsock:socket "bad" &nil; &nil;)))

section.title: Return Values
section.para: The return values of the functions described in section are derived from the return values of the underlying system call: if, say, the &addr-r; argument is modified by the system call, two values are returned (in addition to the possible values coming from the return value of the system call): the (modified) &addr-r; structure and its new size. If the system call fails, an &err-sig;.

section.title: Not Implemented
section.para: We do not interface to select or poll in this module, they are already available through &so-status;.
We do not interface to shutdown in this module, it is already available through &sost-shut;.
We do not interface to gethostbyname or gethostbyaddr in this module, they are already available through &resolve-host;.

variablelist.title: Functions that do not correspond to a single system call

listitem.simpara: Call one of read/readv or write/writev (depending on whether &buf-r; is a &ubyte-vec; or a (&vector-t; &ubyte-vec;)). Return the number of bytes read or written.
When readv and writev and not available, they are emulated by repeated calls to read and write.
On &win32; we have to use recv instead of read and send instead of write because &win32; read and write do not work on sockets, only on regular files.

Call getprotobyname when &proto-r; is a &string-t;, or call getprotobynumber when &proto-r; is an &integer-t;. Return a RAWSOCK:PROTOCOL structure object. When &proto-r; is &nil;, return a &list-t; of all known protocols using setprotoent, getprotoent, and endprotoent.

Call getnetbyname when network is a &string-t;, or call getnetbynumber when network is an &integer-t;. Return a RAWSOCK:NETWORK structure object. When network is &nil;, return a &list-t; of all known networks using setnetent, getnetent, and endnetent.
Call getsockopt and setsockopt, returns and sets individual (for specific option &name-r; and level) and multiple (when &name-r; is &nil; and/or level is &all-k;) options. (See also &so-opt;.)

listitem.para: Convert between &string-t; and &integer-t; IP &addr-r; representations using inet_addr inet_ntoa inet_ntop inet_pton

listitem.simpara: Create a sockaddr object. &data-r; should be a sequence of &ubyte-8; or an &integer-t; (meaning (&make-list; &data-r; :initial-element 0)). When omitted, the standard platform-specific size is used.
Return the numeric family of the sockaddr object.
Return a &fresh; &vector-t; displaced to the data field of the &c-lang; struct sockaddr object.

warning.simpara: Modifying this &vector-t;'s content will modify the &addr-r; argument data!

listitem.simpara: Compute the appropriate protocol checksum and record it in the appropriate location. &buf-r; is assumed to be a suitable packet for the protocol, with the appropriate header etc. The typical packet you send is both &ip; and &tcp; and thus has two checksums, so you would want to call two functions.
Set some socket options and IP &addr-r; with ioctl.
